mmc1 mmc1.docx docx 93007 APPLICATION MOLCAA 9959 S1381-1169(16)30275-8 10.1016/j.molcata.2016.07.025 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 TG profiles of CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composites with different CdV2O6 concentration. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 XRD patterns of CdV2O6, g-C3N4, CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composites. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 SEM and TEM images of pure CdV2O6 (a,b), g-C3N4 (c,d), 18% CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composite (e,f, g) and the map distribution for Cd, V, O, C, N (h). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 XPS spectra of pure g-C3N4, CdV2O6, CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composite. (a) survey XPS spectra; (b) V2p and O1s; (c) N1s and Cd3d; (d) C1s. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 PL spectra (a) and Transient photocurrent responses (b) of pure g-C3N4, CdV2O6 and CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composites. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 UV–vis spectra of CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composites (a) and the estimated band gaps of g-C3N4 and CdV2O6 via K-M equation (b). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Photocatalytic activity of CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composites under visible light irradiation (a) and the corresponding first-order kinetics plot (b). Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Five cycle test of 18% CdV2O6/g-C3N4 sample in RhB degradation. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Photocatalytic activity of 18% CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composite for RhB, MO and phenol degradation. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Photocatalytic activity of 18% CdV2O6/g-C3N4 in the presence of different scavengers. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 Possible schemes for electron–hole separation and transport at the CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composite interface. Fig. 11 Preparation, characterization, and photocatalytic activity of CdV2O6 nanorods decorated g-C3N4 composite Min Cui a Qingyan Nong a Jinxiong Yu a Hongjun Lin c Ying Wu b Xiaole Jiang a Xingzheng Liu a Yiming He a ⁎ a Department of Materials Physics, Zhejiang Normal University, Jinhua, 321004, China Department of Materials Physics Zhejiang Normal University Jinhua 321004 China b Institute of Physical Chemistry, Zhejiang Normal University, Jinhua, 321004, China Institute of Physical Chemistry Zhejiang Normal University Jinhua 321004 China c College of Chemistry and Life Sciences, Zhejiang Normal University, Jinhua, 321004, China College of Chemistry and Life Sciences Zhejiang Normal University Jinhua 321004 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Novel CdV2O6/g-C3N4 hybrid system was synthesized by a facile mixing-calcination method. The photocatalytic test indicated that the decoration of CdV2O6 nanorods on g-C3N4 can significantly promote the photocatalytic activity in RhB degradation under visible light. The optimal CdV2O6/g-C3N4 sample exhibited a degradation rate of 0.041min−1, which is 4.5 times higher than that of pure g-C3N4. Various techniques including N2 adsorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS), and photoluminescence (PL) spectroscopy were applied to investigate the origin of the enhanced photoactivity of CdV2O6/g-C3N4. The results indicated that the enhanced activities were mainly attributed to the interfacial transfer of photogenerated electrons and holes between CdV2O6 and g-C3N4, leading to the effective charge separation in the composite, which were evidenced by photoluminescence spectroscopy and photocurrent analysis. This work may provide some useful information for the future design and practical application of multifunctional hybrids photocatalysts in water purification. Keywords Photocatalysis Visible light g-C3N4 CdV2O6 Heterojunction 1 Introduction Since 1972, semiconductor photocatalysis has shown its great potential in water splitting, CO2 reduction, and organic pollutant removal, and thus attracts considerable research interests. The development of visible-light driven photocatalyst with high efficiency is currently of great interest in view of the practical application of photocatalysis [1–6]. Till to now, various metal vanadate, sulfide, bismuth oxyhalide, and polymer semiconductor photocatalysts, such as Ag3VO4 [1], CdS [2], BiOBr [3], g-C3N4 [4] etc., have been applied for organic pollutants degradation or water splitting. However, the fast recombination of electron and hole pairs still limit their photocatalytic activities, indicating that the modification of these semiconductor photocatlaysts is desirable in order to obtain higher photocatalytic efficiency. Polymeric g-C3N4 is the most stable allotrope of carbon nitride. It has a moderate band gap of 2.70eV and can be used as visible-light driven photocatalyst. Since Wang et al. first reported its photocatalytic activity in water splitting in 2009 [4], this polymeric material attracts many scientists’ interests due to its good stability, visible-light response and low cost. However, just like other pristine semiconductors, the photocatalytic efficiency of g-C3N4 is seriously limited by the fast recombination of photogenerated charge carriers and low surface area. Hence, in order to improve its catalytic efficiency, many methods have been developed, which can be divided into three categories. (1). Introduction of nano/mesoporous structure to improve the specific surface area of g-C3N4 [7,8]; (2) Doping metal or nonmetal element to extend the light absorption range of g-C3N4 [9,10]; (3) Fabrication of heterostructured composite to retard the recombination of charge carriers [11–14]. Particularly, considering that the separation efficiency of photogenerated electron-hole pairs is recognized as the key factor influencing the catalytic activity of a photocatalyst, the last approach is seen as the most efficient way and attracts more attentions than the others. Up to now, a great variety of g-C3N4 based heterojunctions have been developed [10–20], for instance, MVO4 (M=Sm, Fe)/g-C3N4 [15,16], W18O49/g-C3N4 [17], Ag3PO4/g-C3N4 [18], BiOBr/g-C3N4 [19], AgX(X=Br, I)/g-C3N4 [20], S-TiO2/g-C3N4 [21] and WO3/g-C3N4 [22]. They all show significantly higher photoactivity than pure g-C3N4. However, due to the high standard of practical application, it is still necessary to find suitable compounds to further improve the photocatalytic performance of g-C3N4. Transition-metal vanadates (M-V-O) have been reported as active materials in the fields of lithium batteries, sensors, and catalysts. The valence band (VB) of the ternary system consists of hybridized V3d, O2p and transition-metal orbitals (such as Bi 6s, Ag4d, Gd4f), which results in an increase of the VB level and the narrowing of the band gap [23]. Hence, transition-metal vanadates usually have moderate band gaps and show great potential in the field of photocatalysis. Till now, a great deal of metal vanadates including BiVO4 [24], Ag3VO4 [1] and Zn3V2O8 [25] have been reported to exhibit good photocatalytic activity in dye degradation, water splitting or CO2 reduction. Meanwhile, they can act as co-catalysts to promote the catalytic activity of a photocatalyst. For example, Hong et al. reported that the WO3 film modified by BiVO4 showed enhanced photocatalytic activity by 74% relative to bare WO3 [26]. Wang et al. found that the doping of Ag3VO4 could significantly promote the activity of TiO2 in photocatalytic oxidation of gaseous benzene [27]. Especially, the metal vanadate shows great promotion effect on g-C3N4 [9,15,16]. A possible reason is that the chemical reaction between g-C3N4 and metal vanadate easily occurs due to the strong redox property of vanadates, which promotes the formation of chemical bonds between the two semiconductors, favors the charge transfer on the interface, and finally retards the recombination of charge carriers. CdV2O6 is one of the big family of metal vanadates. Recently, Li et al. reported that the complex exhibited moderate photocatalytic activity in methylene blue degradation, indicating its potential in photocatalysis [28]. Combing with the previous analysis, it can be inferred that the coupling of CdV2O6 with g-C3N4 might generate an efficient photocatalyst. However, to the best of our knowledge, no research focused on the photocatlaytic activity of CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composite has been reported. Therefore, in this paper, a novel CdV2O6/g-C3N4 heterojunction was prepared via a simple mixing and calcination method. The photocatalytic test indicates that the prepared composite exhibits excellent activity for rhodamine B (RhB) degradation under visible light irradiation. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalysts preparation All these reagents are analytical pure grade and used without further purification. g-C3N4 was prepared by directly heating melamine at 520°C for 4h. The CdV2O6 nanorods were prepared via a hydrothermal method. Typically, 0.9358g NH4VO3 were dissolved in deionized water (30mL) to obtain solution A. 0.9132g CdCl2·2.5H2O were dissolved in 30mL deionized water to obtain solution B. Then, solution A was added to solution B under vigorous agitation. The pH value of the mixture was adjusted to 5.5 with NH3·H2O (25%) solution. The mixture was then transferred into a 100mL Teflon-lined steel autoclave and heated at 160°C for 24h. After the autoclave was cooled to room temperature, the resulting products were separated by centrifugation, washed with absolute ethanol for 4 times and dried at 60°C. The CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composites were prepared as follows. CdV2O6 nanorods and g-C3N4 with different ratios were added into a motor and then ground for 30min. The resultant mixed powders were put into a crucible with a cover and then heated at 400°C for 2h to obtain CdV2O6/g-C3N4 hybrids with various CdV2O6 contents. 2.2 Photocatalytic test Photocatalytic oxidation of RhB was used as a model reaction to evaluate the photocatalytic activities of CdV2O6/g-C3N4 heterojunction under visible light irradiation. The visible light source is a 350W xenon lamp with two cut-off filters (800 nm> λ >420nm). Before light irradiation, a suspension containing 100mL RhB solution (10mg/L) and 0.2g of catalyst were stirred 1h in the dark. At a given time of intervals, about 8mL of suspension was withdrawn and centrifuged to remove catalyst for analysis. The concentration of RhB was determined by measuring the maximum absorbance at about 554nm using a UV–vis spectrophotometer. Besides RhB, methyl orange (MO) and phenol were also used as the simulated pollutants to investigate the photocatalytic activity of CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composite. The degradation procedures were as same as that of RhB. Trapping experiments were performed to determine the reactive species during the photodegradation of RhB. The detailed process was described elsewhere [29]. 2.3 Characterizations Thermo-gravimetric (TG) analysis (Netzsch STA449) was performed in a thermal analyzer (Netzsch STA449) in air flow (10mL/min) with a heating rate of 10°C/min. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples were recorded on a Philips PW3040/60 X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (40kV/40mA). The N2 physical absorption measurements were carried out at 77K with an Autosorb-1 apparatus (Quantachrome Instruments). The specific surface area was calculated by Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) were performed on a Field emission scanning electron microscope (Hitachi S-4800). UV–vis diffuse reflection spectroscopy was performed on a UV–vis spectrophotometer (PerkinElmer Lambda900). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed by a Quantum 2000 Scanning ESCA Microprobe instrument using AlKα. The C 1s signal was set to a position of 284.6eV. The photoluminescence (PL) spectra of the samples were collected on FLS-920 spectrometer (Edinburgh Instrument), using a Xe lamp (excitation at 365nm) as light source. The transient photocurrent measurements were performed by using a CHI 660B electrochemical workstation with a standard three-electrode cell at room temperature [30]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterizations of CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composites Although pure g-C3N4 has high stability, the previous literatures have proven that chemical reaction between g-C3N4 and coupled oxide semiconductors usually occurs at a low temperature [11,15,31,32], which fastens the decomposition of g-C3N4 and results in the loss of g-C3N4. Hence, TG analysis is necessary to investigate the real concentration of g-C3N4 in the CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composites. Fig. 1 shows the TG profiles of CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composites with different CdV2O6 content. It can be observed that all samples except CdV2O6 have a sharp weight decrease, which can be assigned to the loss of g-C3N4. The weight loss temperature of CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composites is much lower than that of pure g-C3N4, indicating the contribution of CdV2O6 and the interaction between CdV2O6 and g-C3N4. This result is consistent with the previous results [11,15,31,32]. Based on the weight of residual the CdV2O6 concentration in the composites are calculated to be 14.1wt.%, 18.0wt.%, 22.6wt.%, and 30.3wt.%, respectively. Fig. 2 a shows the XRD patterns of CdV2O6, g-C3N4, and CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composites with different of CdV2O6 content. Pure g-C3N4 has one strong characteristic peak at 27.4° [33], while pure CdV2O6 shows strong peaks at 19.9°, 27.0°, 27.6°, 28.8°, 32.2°, 36.0°, 38.4°, 42.0° (PDF# 20-0189). The CdV2O6/g-C3N4 hybrid can be seen as a coexistence of both CdV2O6, g-C3N4 phases, and no other new crystal phases are observed. With increasing CdV2O6 content, the diffraction peaks of CdV2O6 are strengthened gradually, whereas those of g-C3N4 are weakened simultaneously. The morphology of the CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composite was investigated by SEM and TEM. As Fig. 3 a and c show, the appearance of CdV2O6 is rod-like, while g-C3N4 polymer is shown as an aggregation of many smaller particles. The morphologies of the two semiconductors also can be proven via their TEM images (Fig. 3b and d). Fig. 3e displays the SEM image of 18% CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composite. It can be observed that CdV2O6 nanorods are randomly embedded on the surface of g-C3N4, suggesting its composite structure. EDS analysis was performed to further confirm the result. The obtained data (Fig. S1) indicates that the sample consists of Cd (2.81%), V (5.45%), O (2.81%), C (33.0%) and N (41.9%), confirming the coexistence of g-C3N4 and CdV2O6. Additionally, it can be noted that the CdV2O6 content via EDS is higher than that from TG analysis. Considering that the dispersion of CdV2O6 in the composite is not uniform, the discordance may be because the detected area contains more CdV2O6 particles. Fig. 3f shows the TEM image of 18% CdV2O6/g-C3N4 hybrid. Due to the different shape of the two semiconductors, it is clearly observed that CdV2O6 nanorods disperse finely in g-C3N4 sheets, which is also verified via the element mapping of the composite (Fig. 3h) and agrees well with the result of XRD. The high resolution TEM image of 18% CdV2O6/g-C3N4 is shown in Fig. 3g. The left portion of the figure which displays clear lattice fringe can be assigned to CdV2O6 phase, while the rest part is g-C3N4. The two semiconductors exhibit smooth and intimate interface, indicating that the ultrasonic treatment of the sample before the TEM analysis does not peel off g-C3N4 or CdV2O6. CdV2O6 nanorods are closed adhered on g-C3N4 sheets, which is beneficial for the formation of CdV2O6/g-C3N4 heterojunction. Fig. 4 shows the XPS spectra of g-C3N4, CdV2O6 and a representative catalyst 18% CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composite. The survey XPS spectra indicates that g-C3N4 is mainly composed of C and N element, while CdV2O6 consists of Cd, V, and O elements. For CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composite, all signals of C1s, N1s, Cd3d, V2p and O1s are detected, consistent with its hybrid structure. The high resolution XPS spectra of these elements are provided to further analyze their oxidation state. The binding energy (BE) of V2p3/2 and 2p1/2 is determined to be 516.7 and 524.1eV, respectively, corresponding to the V5+ in CdV2O6 (Fig. 4b) [34]. The BE of Cd3d5/2 and 3d3/2 locate at 404.6 and 411.3eV, respectively, indicating the existence of Cd2+ (Fig. 4c) [35]. The O1s spectrum of CdV2O6/g-C3N4 can be divided to two individual peaks (Fig. 4b). The peak at 529.6eV can be assigned to the lattice oxygen from CdV2O6 [36], while the peak of 532.4eV can be ascribed to the absorbed H2O or OH species on g-C3N4 [37]. In Fig. 4d, the CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composite presents two C1s peaks at 284.6eV and 288.0eV, corresponding to the adventitious carbon and the NCN coordination in g-C3N4 [37], which is similar to that of pure g-C3N4. The slightly higher C1s BE of CdV2O6/g-C3N4 than g-C3N4 is ascribed to the electron transfer from the electron-rich g-C3N4 to CdV2O6, leads to the decreased electron density of g-C3N4 [12,38], which is a common phenomenon in the g-C3N4 based composite photocatalysts. The XPS analysis clearly verifies the existence of strong interaction between CdV2O6 and g-C3N4, demonstrating the hybrid structure of the CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composite rather than a simple physical mixture. It is widely accepted that the strong interaction between the consisting components can benefit the formation of heterojunction structure and the separation of electron-hole pairs, which may result in a high photocatalytic activity of the composite [17–22,38,39]. Herein, the interactions between CdV2O6 and g-C3N4 have been proven, indicating that the CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composite should hold enhanced separation efficiency of electron-hole pairs than pure g-C3N4. In order to verify this inference, PL and transient photocurrent experiments were performed to investigate the fate of electron–hole pairs in CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composite. Fig. 5 displays the PL spectra of pure g-C3N4, CdV2O6 and CdV2O6/g-C3N4 with different CdV2O6 concentrations. Pure CdV2O6 shows no peak in the range of 400–600nm, whereas pure g-C3N4 presents a strong emission peak at approximate 460nm, which accords well with the reported results [17–22]. Nevertheless, in the PL spectra of the CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composites, a weaker emission peak in the same position is observed, and 18% CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composite displays the weakest PL peak. Generally, PL emission results from the recombination of generated electrons and holes. The stronger PL peak usually represents the higher the recombination efficiency of the charge carriers and the lower photocatalytic activity [40,41]. Hence, the result in Fig. 5a indicates that the photoexcited charge recombination rate of CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composite is much slower than that of g-C3N4, while the 18% CdV2O6/g-C3N4 sample holds the best capability in charge separation. Besides the PL technique, the transient photocurrent experiment is widely used as an efficient approach to demonstrate the charge separation in composite photocatalysts [42,43]. The stronger photocurrent intensity usually indicates the higher separation efficiency of electron-hole pairs. Fig. 5b shows the transient photocurrent response of g-C3N4, CdV2O6 and CdV2O6/g-C3N4 samples under visible-light irradiation. Fast and uniform photocurrent responses are observed in both electrodes. Pure g-C3N4 shows a higher photocurrent than CdV2O6. For CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composites, the photocurrents are much higher. 18% CdV2O6/g-C3N4 electrode exhibits the highest photocurrent of 0.17μA, which is approximately 3 times higher than that of g-C3N4 electrode. This result is consistent with the PL analysis, and clearly proves that the introduction of CdV2O6 phase into g-C3N4 significantly retards the recombination of photogenerated charge carriers. The optical properties of CdV2O6/g-C3N4 hybrids were characterized by DRS. As Fig. 6 shows, both g-C3N4 and CdV2O6 exhibit optical absorption from UV light to visible light. Considering that the two samples are indirect gap semiconductors [28,44], the band gap of the two semiconductor can be estimated via the Kubelka-Munk equation [17,18]. The result in Fig. 6b indicates that the estimated band gaps of CdV2O6 and g-C3N4 are 2.54 and 2.70eV, respectively. Clearly, the band gap of CdV2O6 is slightly narrower than that of g-C3N4, indicating its better light absorption ability. Therefore, the visible light responses of the CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composites are enhanced by the introduction of CdV2O6, just as shown in Fig. 6. The enhanced optical property may contribute to the photocatalytic process and result in an enhancement in photoactivity. The specific surface areas of CdV2O6/g-C3N4 hybrids are characterized via N2 adsorption experiments. The BET surface area of g-C3N4 is 11m2/g, which is higher than that of CdV2O6 (3.5m2/g). The CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composites have nearly the same specific surface areas. For the samples with CdV2O6 content of 14.1%, 18.0%, 22.6%, 30.3%, the BET value is 13.1, 12.7, 13.1 and 13.0m2/g, respectively. 3.2 Photocatalytic activity of CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composites The photocatalytic activities of as-synthesized CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composites were evaluated by the degradation of RhB under visible light irradiation. Fig. 7 a shows the photocatalytic activity of CdV2O6, g-C3N4, and CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composites. The blank test indicates that RhB is stable under visible-light irradiation, suggesting that the self-degradation of RhB can be neglected. For the reaction with a photocatalyst, it can be observed that the RhB concentration decreases after one hour of adsorption in the dark, which is ascribed to the adsorption of RhB on the photocatalyst surface. Obviously, CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composites exhibit better adsorption of RhB than pure g-C3N4 or CdV2O6. Under visible light irradiation, the RhB concentration decreases even faster. 50% of RhB removal is achieved over g-C3N4 after 50min of visible light irradiation, indicating its moderate photocatalytic activity. This result is consistent with the reported literature [30]. Different from g-C3N4, the pristine CdV2O6 presents very weak ability in RhB degradation. Nevertheless, when CdV2O6 is coupled with g-C3N4, the photocatalytic activity is increased significantly because of the enhanced separation efficiency of electrons and holes. With the increase of CdV2O6 content from 14.1% to 30.3%, the photocatalytic activity increases gradually and then decreases. The highest degradation rate is obtained over 18% CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composite. A pseudo-first-order model was employed to investigate the kinetics of RhB degradation. The result is shown in Fig. 7b. It is observed that the removal rate constant (k) of the samples accords well with the result in Fig. 7a. The 18% CdV2O6/g-C3N4 sample exhibits optimal k value of 0.041min−1, which is 4.5 times higher than that of g-C3N4. The COD removal and the cycle test of the 18%CdV2O6/g-C3N4 sample are also performed to further assess the mineralization ability and the stability of the composite. The COD measurements of the RhB solution before and after reaction were determined by the open reflux method, using a potassium permanganate solution as the oxidizing agent in a strong acid medium [45]. The result shows that RhB dye is mineralized by 74% within 50min irradiation time, suggesting the dye is efficiently degraded. Fig. 8 shows the five recycling runs of 18% CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composite for RhB degradation under visible light. After each cycling experiment, the photocatalyst was washed with deionized water and dried. The CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composite maintains a similar level of reactivity after five runs of experiments. The slight decrease may originate from the inescapable loss of catalyst during the recycling runs. This result indicates that the synthesized CdV2O6/g-C3N4 hybrid has high stability in the purification of dye solution. Additionally, the extensive adaptability of the CdV2O6/g-C3N4 photocatalyst is also investigated. The result shown in Fig. 9 indicates that the CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composite can also efficiently degrade MO besides RhB. For phenol, the degradation efficiency of 55% is achieved under visible light irradiation for 120min. Given that the phenol content is twice of that of dyes, this photoactivity is acceptable. Meanwhile, since phenol is colorless and only responses to UV light, the result indicates that the contribution of the dye self-photosensitized effect for the phoactivity of CdV2O6/g-C3N4 hybrid may be ignored. Fig. 10 shows the photocatalytic activity of 18% CdV2O6/g-C3N4 hybrid in the presence of different scavengers which are used to trap the reactive species. In general, the reduced extent of the photoactivity represents the important of the reactive species in the reaction. The addition of isopropanol (IPA, a quencher of OH) [29,38] shows nearly no effect on the photocatalytic reaction, indicating that OH is not the major active species. In the presence of benzoquinone (BQ, a quencher of O2 −) [29,38] and KI (a quencher of h+ and OH) [29,46], the degradation rate for RhB decreases apparently. Thus, O2 − and h+ are proved to play key roles in the photocatalytic process for CdV2O6/g-C3N4 photocatalyst. 3.3 Discussion for the enhanced photoactivity of CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composites Therefore, it is no doubt that the coupling of CdV2O6 with g-C3N4 generates an efficient photocatalyst with high stability. The introduced CdV2O6 modifies the physicochemical property of g-C3N4, which may result in the enhanced photocatalytic activity. On the basis of the above experimental results, it can be concluded that the added CdV2O6 increases the photoabsorption performance, the surface area and the separation efficiency of electron-hole pairs. Generally, all the changes are beneficial for the photocatalytic reaction and contribute to the enhanced photocatalytic activity. However, a detailed analysis is still needed to probe which one is the dominant reason. For the photoabsorption performance, it widely accepted that this property dominates the number of generated electrons and holes in a photocatalyst. Nevertheless, because most of the generated electrons and holes are recombined, the consistency between the light absorption ability and the photoactivity is seldom observed. So is the current case of CdV2O6/g-C3N4. The sample with the best photoabsorption performance (30.3% CdV2O6/g-C3N4) does not present the highest photocatalytic activity, demonstrating that the optical absorption is not the key factor. A similar relationship between the surface area and the photocatalytic activity is also observed. The N2 adsorption experiment proves that the CdV2O6/g-C3N4 hybrids present higher BET surface area than g-C3N4 or CdV2O6, which induces the better ability in RhB adsorption and fastens the degradation of RhB on the surface of photocatalysts. However, it should be noted that the BET surface areas of the composites are in the same order of magnitude, and all the CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composites display similar capability in RhB adsorption, which is inconsistent with their photocatalytic activities. Therefore, neither the BET surface area nor the light absorption ability determines the photocatalytic activity of the CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composite. The enhanced photocatalytic activity should be mainly ascribed to the increased separation efficiency of electron-hole pairs. In order to explore the mechanism for the enhanced separation efficiency of charge carriers in the CdV2O6/g-C3N4 composite, the band edge positions of the VB and conduction band (CB) of CdV2O6 and g-C3N4 are investigated. The band structure of g-C3N4 has been studied thoroughly. It has been widely accepted that the VB and CB edges are locates at 1.50 and −1.20eV, respectively [31]. For CdV2O6 semiconductor, the valence band (VB) and conduction band (CB) positions can be calculated via the equations of EVB =X − Ec +1/2 Eg and ECB =EVB −Eg based on the reported literatures [39,47,48]. The ECB and EVB values are estimated to be 0.24 and 2.78eV, respectively (Table S1). Obviously, the two semiconductors, CdV2O6 and g-C3N4, have suitable band potentials and can fabricate a heterojunction structure in the composite. As shown in Fig. 11 , under visible light irradiation both CdV2O6 and g-C3N4 can be excited to generate electron and holes. The photoexcited electrons on g-C3N4 can transfer to the CB of CdV2O6 due to its higher CB position than that of CdV2O6. At the same time, the photogenerated holes on CdV2O6 can move to the VB of g-C3N4. The charge transfer effectively retards the recombination of electron–hole pairs, therefore resulting in the significantly high efficiency of photo-decomposition of RhB dyes. 4 Conclusion Novel high-efficiency CdV2O6/g-C3N4 hybrids were successfully prepared via a simple mixing and calcinations method. The decoration of CdV2O6 nanorods on g-C3N4 sheets can lead to significant improvement on the photocatalytic activities for RhB degradation under visible light irradiation. The obviously enhanced activity could be mainly attributed to the effective separation of electron–hole pairs at the interface of the heterojunction, leading to the low recombination rate of charge carriers, which is evidenced by transient photocurrent and PL studies. This study may provide a potential approach to the environmental purification of organic pollutants using sunlight. coredata.dc:description: Novel CdV2O6/g-C3N4 hybrid system was synthesized by a facile mixing-calcination method. The photocatalytic test indicated that the decoration of CdV2O6 nanorods on g-C3N4 can significantly promote the photocatalytic activity in RhB degradation under visible light. The optimal CdV2O6/g-C3N4 sample exhibited a degradation rate of 0.041min−1, which is 4.5 times higher than that of pure g-C3N4. Various techniques including N2 adsorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS), and photoluminescence (PL) spectroscopy were applied to investigate the origin of the enhanced photoactivity of CdV2O6/g-C3N4. The results indicated that the enhanced activities were mainly attributed to the interfacial transfer of photogenerated electrons and holes between CdV2O6 and g-C3N4, leading to the effective charge separation in the composite, which were evidenced by photoluminescence spectroscopy and photocurrent analysis. This work may provide some useful information for the future design and practical application of multifunctional hybrids photocatalysts in water purification.
coredata.dc:title: Preparation, characterization, and photocatalytic activity of CdV2O6 nanorods decorated g-C3N4 composite
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
